revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Goal Line Technology Diagram.png|thumb|right|Diagram of a Goal Line Technology system based around sensors in the ball and goal frame. Most operational systems instead use cameras to track the ball ]] In [[association football]], '''goal-line technology''' (sometimes referred to as a '''Goal Decision System''')<ref>{{cite web|title=Wenger praise for Goal Decision System|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2013-14/aug/arsene-wenger-praise-for-goal-decision-system.html|publisher=PremierLeague.com|accessdate=10 August 2013|date=8 August 2013}}</ref> is the use of electronic aid to determine if a [[Scoring in association football|goal]] has been scored or not. In detail, it is a method used to determine when the ball has completely crossed the goal line in between the goal-posts and underneath the crossbar with the assistance of electronic devices and at the same time assisting the [[Referee (association football)|referee]] in awarding a goal or not. The objective of goal-line technology (GLT) is not to replace the role of the officials, but rather to support them in their decision-making. The GLT must provide a clear indication as to whether the ball has fully crossed the line, and this information will serve to assist the referee in making his final decision.<ref>{{cite journal|last=FIFA|title=Testing Manual|journal=FIFA Quality Programme for Goal Line Technology|year=2012|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/fifaqualityprogramme/goal-linetechnology/01/66/02/89/glt_testing_manual_2012.pdf}}</ref>
Compared to similar technology in other sports, goal-line technology is a relatively recent addition to association football; its integration having been opposed by the sport's authorities. In July 2012, the [[International Football Association Board]] (IFAB) officially approved the use of goal line technology, amending the [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]] to permit (but not require) its use. Due to its expense, goal-line technology is only used at the highest levels of the game. Goal-line technology is currently used in the top European domestic leagues, and at major international competitions such as the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 Men's]]<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1117/2.2201406.01| title = Keeping an eye on the ball| journal = SPIE Newsroom| year = 2014| last1 = Thomas | first1 = K. }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=4/news=goal-line-technology-set-ahead-fifa-world-cup-2311481.html|title=Goal-line technology set up ahead of FIFA World Cup|first=|last=FIFA.com|date=1 April 2014|publisher=}}</ref>, [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 Men's]]<ref>https://football-technology.fifa.com/en/blog/hidden-technologies-at--2018-fwc/</ref> and [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup|2015 Women's]] FIFA World Cups.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/news/y=2015/m=3/news=hawk-eye-confirmed-as-goal-line-technology-provider-for-canada-2015-2580727.html |title=Hawk-Eye confirmed as goal-line technology provider for Canada 2015 |date=31 March 2015 |publisher=[[FIFA]] |access-date=2 June 2015}}]</ref>
==Background== {{seealso|Scoring in association football}} In association football, a [[Goal (sport)#Association football|goal]] is scored if the whole of the ball crosses the [[Football pitch|goal line]] between the [[goalpost]]s and under the crossbar. In most cases, this is relatively unambiguous (goal nets being a low-tech way of verifying that the ball passed the correct side of the goalposts). Occasionally however situations occur when it is difficult for [[referee (association football)|referee]]s and their [[Assistant referee (association football)|assistant]]s to tell if a goal has been scored before a rebound, save, or defender's clearance from the goal area.
==Rules== Since 2012, goal-line technology has been permitted in matches. Text relating to goal-line technology can now be found within four of the Laws of the Game:
*'''Law 1 ([[Football pitch|The Field of Play]])''': permitting modifications to the goal frame. *'''Law 2 ([[Ball (association football)|The Ball]])''': permitting the use of approved balls with integrated technology. *'''Law 5 ([[Referee (association football)|The Referee]])''': requiring the referee to test a goal-line technology system prior to a match and not use it if a fault is found. *'''Law 10 ([[Scoring in association football|The Method of Scoring]])''': permitting use of goal-line technology to verify whether or not goals have been scored. It states that "the use of GLT must be stipulated in the respective competition rules".
The Laws themselves are not specific as to the nature of Goal Line technology systems, however other documentation from FIFA, which is cited by the Laws, goes into more detail. The ''FIFA Quality Programme for GLT Testing Manual''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quality.fifa.com/en/News/Updated-goal-line-technology-testing-manual-published/|title=Updated goal-line technology testing manual published - FIFA Quality Programme|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150515115539/http://quality.fifa.com/en/News/Updated-goal-line-technology-testing-manual-published/|archivedate=15 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> precisely define the requirements of the systems. Four basic requirements of a system are stipulated:
*The system must address ''only'' the matter of whether a goal has been scored or not. *The system must be accurate. *The system must indicate the scoring of a goal immediately, confirming this within one second. *The system must communicate its information solely to the match officials (via vibration and visual alert on the referee's watch)
FIFA have a system whereby a particular technology provider needs to show effectiveness to successfully obtain a license for their technology, then an installation within a particular stadium must pass a "final installation test" before use, and before each game the referee must check that the system is functional.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://football-technology.fifa.com/media/1011/goal-line_technology_testing_manual_2014.pdf|title=TESTING MANUAL 2014 version 2.0|last=|first=|date=|year=2014|website=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA Quality Programme for Goal-Line Technology|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://quality.fifa.com/en/Goal-Line-Technology/Become-a-licensee/Final-installation-test/|title=Final installation test - FIFA Quality Programme|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706221701/http://quality.fifa.com/en/Goal-Line-Technology/Become-a-licensee/Final-installation-test/|archivedate=6 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Current implementation== Due to the expense of goal-line technology systems, the technology is only currently used at the very top levels of the game. In domestic competition, goal-line technology is only regularly used in a few major European leagues: [[Serie A]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Serie A approves goal-line technology for next season|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/italian-serie-a/story/2297461/serie-a-approves-goal-line-technology-for-next-season|accessdate=6 January 2016|work=ESPN FC|date=13 February 2015}}</ref> [[Ligue 1]],<ref name="Ligue1_GLT">{{cite web|title=LFP adopts goal-line technology|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lfp-adopts-goal-line-technology.htm|website=Ligue1.com|accessdate=6 January 2016|date=17 April 2015}}</ref> the [[Bundesliga]],<ref name="Bundasliga">{{cite news|title=Bundesliga to use goalline technology from 2015-16 season|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30336984|accessdate=6 January 2016|work=BBC|date=4 December 2014}}</ref> and the [[Premier League]].<ref name="Premier_league">{{cite news|title=Goal-line technology: Premier League votes in favour for 2013-14|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22107409|accessdate=6 January 2016|work=BBC|date=11 April 2013}}</ref>
{{Asof|September 2018}}, FIFA's website list 167 stadiums with licensed GLT installations, 166 of which use the [[Hawk-Eye]] system.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://football-technology.fifa.com/en/resource-hub/certified-product-database/goal-line-technology/installations/|title=FOOTBALL TECHNOLOGY - Resource Hub|publisher=FIFA}}</ref> One stadium uses [[GoalControl]],<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://football-technology.fifa.com/en/resource-hub/certified-product-database/goal-line-technology/installations/|title=FOOTBALL TECHNOLOGY - Resource Hub|publisher=FIFA}}</ref> which is the other licensed provider.<ref>{{cite web |title=Football Technology - Installations |url=https://football-technology.fifa.com/en/resource-hub/certified-product-database/goal-line-technology/installations/ |website=|publisher=FIFA |accessdate=16 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==History==
===Pre-implementation history=== Prior to 2012, competitions were unable to implement technology as provision was not made for it in the Laws. The Laws of association football are controlled by the [[International Football Association Board]] (IFAB), a body on which FIFA holds 50% of the voting power, sufficient to veto any changes to the laws.
====Pre-2011==== Compared to other sports, association football was late to allow technology to assist with in-game decisions. The matter was a subject of debate within the game for over a decade with the game's lawmakers resisting calls for its implementation.
Throughout the 2000s various incidents incited discussion as to the potential for goal-line technology in the game.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nigerian media bitter in defeat|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/africa/cup_of_nations/cup_news/642400.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=14 February 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4130167.stm |title=Manchester United 0-0 Tottenham |publisher=BBC News |date=4 January 2005 |accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/aug/15/crystal-palace-neil-warnock-freddie-sears |title = Neil Warnock furious as 'phantom goal' costs Crystal Palace |first = Herman |last = Miller |date = 15 August 2009 |location=London |work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/aug/17/bristol-city-palace-no-replay |title = Bristol City-Crystal Palace game will not be replayed |date = 17 August 2009 | location=London |work=The Guardian}}</ref> The lack of use of technology in association football was contrasted with other sports, which had incorporated video replays and other systems into their rules.<ref name="UK_PM">{{cite news|last1=Emery|first1=Daniel|title=PM and goal-line technology firms dispute Fifa claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10435509|accessdate=23 April 2015|work=BBC|date=28 June 2010}}</ref>
In response to this, FIFA decided to test a system by [[Adidas]] in which a football with an embedded [[integrated circuit|microchip]] would send a signal to the referee if it crossed a sensor going through the goal.<ref name="geekweek1">{{cite web|url=http://www.geekweek.com/2010/04/goal-line-technology-cross-too-many-lines-for-fifa-1.html |title=Goal-Line Technology: Crossing Too Many Lines For FIFA? |publisher=GeekWeek |date=19 April 2010 |first=Liam |last=McGrath |accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref> According to FIFA president [[Sepp Blatter]], "We did different tests at the [[2005 FIFA U-17 World Championship|Under-17 World Cup in Peru]] but the evidence wasn't clear so we will carry out trials in junior competitions in 2007".<ref name="geekweek1" /> However, those trials did not materialise and by 2008, Blatter had rejected the system outright, describing the technology as 'only 95% accurate'.<ref name="geekweek1" /> FIFA and IFAB were resistant to introducing technology in the game, voting in March 2010 to permanently ditch the technology.<ref>{{cite news|title=Football's lawmakers reject goal-line technology|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8553463.stm|accessdate=23 April 2015|work=BBC|date=6 March 2010}}</ref>
Following several refereeing errors at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] – including the disallowed goal in [[Germany national football team|Germany]]'s 4–1 victory over [[England national football team|England]], when [[Frank Lampard]] hit a shot from outside of the penalty box that bounced off the crossbar and over the line; the ball came back out and the goal was disallowed because the [[Assistant referee (association football)|assistant referee]] did not call for a goal<ref>{{cite news |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2010/soccer/world-cup-2010/writers/jonathan_wilson/06/28/soccer.technology/index.html |title = Soccer could use instant replay, but not at expense of the sport's flow |first = Jonathan |last = Wilson |date = 28 June 2010 |work=CNN}}</ref> – Blatter announced that FIFA would reopen the goal-line technology discussion.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/30/sports/soccer/30ref.html?hp|title=FIFA President Apologizes for Refereeing Errors|date=29 June 2010|work=NY Times|accessdate=29 June 2010 | first=Jeffrey | last=Marcus}}</ref>
Before [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]], [[UEFA]] president [[Michel Platini]] dismissed the need for goal-line technology, instead arguing for placing additional assistant referees behind the goal. However, in a Group D match with [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] losing 1–0 to [[England national football team|England]], the on-field officials did not see Ukraine's [[Marko Dević]]'s shot briefly cross the line before it was cleared by England's [[John Terry]], although an offside in the build-up to the incident was too unnoticed by the match officials.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9343883/Euro-2012-Ukraines-ghost-goal-against-England-another-example-of-why-we-need-goal-line-technology-says-Sepp-Blatter.html|title=Euro 2012: Ukraine's ghost goal against England another example of why we need goal-line technology, says Sepp Blatter|work=The Daily Telegrapgh|date=20 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/rooney-seizes-his-chance-to-lift-englands-expectations-7866807.html|title=Rooney seizes his chance to lift England's expectations |work=The Independent|date=20 June 2012|accessdate=20 June 2012}}</ref>
====Initial testing==== [[File:Teamgeist II adidas.jpg|thumb|The [[Adidas]] Teamgeist II with implanted chip, part of the proposed Cairos-Adidas system for goal-line technology]] Heeding calls for the use of technology, in July 2011 FIFA began a process of sanctioned tests that eventually resulted in the approval of the systems used in the current game.
The first stage of testing considered multiple goal-line technology systems, with the requirement that the system notified the referee of the decision within one second of the incident happening. The message needed to be relayed via a visual signal and vibration.<ref name="july 2011">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jul/21/fifa-goal-line-technology | work=[[The Guardian]] | title=Fifa to run tests on nine goal-line technology systems this autumn | date=21 July 2011 | location=London}}</ref> Tests were conducted by [[Empa]] between September and December 2011.<ref name="March 2012 IFAB/FIFA">{{cite news|last=Conway|first=Richard|title=Goal-line technology edges closer |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17228500|accessdate=3 March 2012|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=15 April 2012}}</ref> Tested systems included:<ref name="March 2012 IFAB/FIFA" />
* A system from [[Carios Technologies]], in collaboration with [[Adidas]], based around a modified ball with an implanted chip and a magnetic field generated by thin cables behind the goal line. The system could detect if the ball passed through the field.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wipo.int/wipo_magazine/en/2010/04/article_0001.html |title=Goal-line technology – Getting it right |publisher=[[The WIPO Journal]] |date=August 2010 |accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> * [[GoalRef]]: Another system based on generated magnetic fields and a sensor within the ball.<ref name="belgium/eng announcement" /> * Goalminder: A system based on cameras installed in the goal frame. This provided a visual playback to officials rather than an automatic goal-or-no-goal alert.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goalminder.co.uk/ |title=About Goalminder - Goal Line Technology - Visually Informed |accessdate=13 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215103841/http://www.goalminder.co.uk/ |archivedate=15 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/business/enterprise/s/1461303_goalminder-aims-to-end-goal-line-errors |title=Goalminder aims to end goal-line errors |date=11 October 2011 |publisher=menmedia.co.uk |accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> * [[Hawk-Eye]]: A [[Sony]]-owned system based several on multiple high-speed cameras whose images are used to which [[Triangulation|triangulate]] the position of the ball.<ref name="belgium/eng announcement" /> Hawk-Eye systems were, and still are, used in several other sports for supporting officiating decisions.<ref>{{cite news |title = Sport technology enables improved decisions |date = 11 October 2011 |first = David |last = Boothroyd |url = http://www.newelectronics.co.uk/electronics-technology/sport-technology-enables-improved-decisions/37425/}}</ref>
====Second phase of testing==== On 3 March 2012, [[IFAB]] announced that two of the eight proposed systems had proceeded to the second stage of testing. These were Hawk-Eye and GoalRef.<ref name="March 2012 IFAB/FIFA"/> In the second phase of testing, the manufacturer of the technology chose a stadium to test its technology in a number of imagined scenarios. Testing was also conducted in professional training sessions and in laboratories to account for different climatic conditions and other magnetic field distortions. There were also tests on the watches to be worn by referees. The systems underwent testing in some competitive matches.
GoalRef technology underwent match testing in some [[Danish Superliga]] matches in the first half of 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dbu.dk/Nyheder/2012/Maj/FIFA_tester_teknologi.aspx |title=FIFA tester teknologi i Silkeborg og Farum |last=Berendt |first=Lars |publisher=[[Danish Football Association]] |language=Danish |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sciencenordic.com/ball-tells-you-when-it%E2%80%99s|title=The ball tells you when it’s in|publisher=}}</ref> Following the second phase trials, on 5 July 2012 IFAB approved GoalRef in principle, making it available for use in professional matches under a set of revised [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]]. Each installation however would also require licensing approval for use in the individual stadium, on a 12-month basis. The [[2012 FIFA Club World Cup]] was the first tournament where GoalRef was used by a match referee. Goal Ref was used for the first time on 6 December 2012 in the first match of the 2012 FIFA Club World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/fifa-give-debut-to-goalline-technology-in-world-club-curtainraiser-3317352.html |title= FIFA give debut to goal-line technology in World club curtain-raiser|date=6 December 2012 |work=Irish Independent|accessdate=6 December 2012 }}</ref>
The first match to use the Hawk-Eye goal-line technology was [[Eastleigh F.C.]] versus [[A.F.C. Totton]] in the [[Hampshire Senior Cup]] final at [[St Mary's Stadium]], [[Southampton]] in [[England]] on 16 May 2012. Although it used Hawk-Eye, the system had no bearing on the referee's decisions and the system readings were only available to [[FIFA]]'s independent testing agency.<ref name="April bbc">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17874013 | title=Non-league final to be used for goal-line technology experiment | date=27 April 2012 | work=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref> The system was also in place for the technology's second test on 2 June for [[England national football team|England]]'s [[friendly match]] against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]].<ref name="belgium/eng announcement">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/may/24/england-belgium-goalline-technology | title=England friendly against Belgium to be big test of goalline technology | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | date=24 May 2012 | location=London | first=Jamie | last=Jackson}}</ref>
===Introduction=== [[File:Dzeko city.jpg|thumb|[[Edin Džeko]] of Manchester City scored the first goal in the Premier League that was given by goal-line technology]] Following the success of the trials, in July 2012 IFAB voted unanimously to officially amend the Laws of the Game to permit (but not require) goal-line technology.<ref name=IFABofficial>{{cite web|title=IFAB makes three unanimous historic decisions|url=https://www.fifa.com/about-fifa/news/y=2012/m=7/news=ifab-makes-three-unanimous-historic-decisions-1660541.html|website=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
In December 2012, [[FIFA]] announced it would introduce goal-line technology at the [[2012 FIFA Club World Cup]] in [[Japan]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/FIFA-set-to-introduce-goal-line-technology/tabid/415/articleID/279404/Default.aspx/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Goal-line tech gets green light| date=6 December 2012}}</ref> [[Hawk-Eye]] technology was employed at [[Toyota Stadium]], while GoalRef was used at [[International Stadium Yokohama]].
[[GoalControl]], a camera-based system which uses 14 high-speed cameras located around the pitch and directed at both goals, was used at [[2013 Confederations Cup]], partly as a trial for use at the next year's [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/02/fifa-goalline-technology-snub-hawkeye|title= Fifa snubs Hawk-Eye in favour of German goalline technology|date=2 April 2013|work=Guardian|accessdate=4 April 2013|location=London|first=Dominic|last=Fifield}}</ref><ref name="BBCgoalcontrol">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22002733 | title=GoalControl to provide goal-line system at World Cup in Brazil | publisher=BBC | date=2 April 2013 | accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref>
[[The Football Association]] announced that Hawk-Eye would be used in the [[2013–14 Premier League|2013–14 Premier League season]].<ref name="BBC_Premier">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22107409 | title=Goal-line technology: Premier League votes in favour for 2013-14 | work=BBC | date=2013-04-11 | accessdate=2013-04-11}}</ref> On 16 December 2013, it was announced that Hawk-Eye would be used in three of the four quarter-finals and subsequent matches in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>BBC: [https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25405720 Football League to use goal-line technology in Capital One Cup]</ref> The system was used when, on the very next day, in the [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] – [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] quarter-final, a goal from Frank Lampard was allowed.<ref>BBC: [https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25312545 Sunderland 2-1 Chelsea]</ref> The first goal to be decisively awarded using goal-line technology in the English Premier League was [[Edin Džeko]]'s goal for [[Manchester City]] against [[Cardiff City]] on 18 January 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title=Arsenal stay top, technology aids Manchester City |date=19 January 2014 |first=Tom |last= Williams |url= http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/arsenal-stay-top-technology-aids-manchester-city-20140119-3124s.html |work=Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
Following success at the Confederations Cup, GoalControl was used at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]. The first goal given by the technology was in the 15 June 2014 [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group E#France vs Honduras|group stage match]] between [[France national football team|France]] and [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]].<ref>{{cite news|title=France 3-0 Honduras|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285092|accessdate=15 June 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=15 June 2014}}</ref>
Goal Line Technology was implemented across the major European competitions. In December 2014, the [[Bundesliga]] clubs approved goal-line technology that will be introduced at the start of the [[2015–16 Bundesliga]] season. The league picked the cheaper Hawk-Eye system over two German technologies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carlyleobserver.com/sports/bundesliga-approves-hawk-eye-goal-line-technology-for-new-season-1.1650074|title=Bundesliga approves Hawk-Eye goal-line technology for new season|publisher=}}</ref> GoalControl was introduced for [[Ligue 1]] for the start of the [[2015–16 Ligue 1]] season.<ref>http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lfp-adopts-goal-line-technology.htm</ref><ref name="GC_L1">{{cite web |title=Ligue 1 decides to go with GoalControl {{!}} GoalControl - Advanced Goal Line Technology |url=https://www.goalcontrol.de/en/news/2015/05/21/ligue-1-entscheidet-sich-f%C3%BCr-goalcontrol/ |website=www.goalcontrol.de |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> Ligue 1 later switched to using Hawk-Eye in 2018 after the GoalControl system made errors.<ref name="L1-GC-HE">{{cite news |last1=Holyman |first1=Ian |title=Hawk-Eye to provide goal-line tech in Ligue 1 |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/french-ligue-1/story/3472391/hawk-eye-to-provide-goal-line-tech-in-ligue-1-after-goal-control-deal-ended |accessdate=13 July 2018 |work=ESPN.com |date=26 April 2018}}</ref>
Goal Line Technology was used in the [[UEFA Europa League]] final, [[UEFA Champions League]], [[UEFA European Championship|European Championship]] and [[Copa America]] for the first time in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35726091|title=Goalline technology to be used in Champions League final|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jan/22/uefa-goal-line-technology-euro-2016|title=Uefa to use goal-line technology at Euro 2016 and in Champions League|first=Press|last=Association|date=22 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/copa-america-use-goal-line-technology#:b-aD2lVKTshaWA|title=Copa America to use goal-line technology|date=26 May 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
==Criticism==
===Human element is lost=== While advocates for goal-line technology maintain that it would significantly reduce refereeing errors during play, there are also criticisms of the technology. Much of the criticism came from within FIFA itself including former FIFA president [[Sepp Blatter]]. Apart from the criticisms revolving around the technical aspects of the two proposed technologies, critics point out that such technology would impact on the human element of the game and remove the enjoyment of debating mistakes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kelso |first=Paul |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup-2010/teams/england/7857951/England-v-Germany-Frank-Lampards-goal-reignites-goal-line-technology-debate.html |title=England v Germany: Frank Lampard's 'goal' reignites goal-line technology debate |newspaper=The Telegraph |date= 27 June 2010|accessdate=28 June 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Sepp Blatter has been quoted as saying "Other sports regularly change the laws of the game to react to the new technology. ... We don't do it and this makes the fascination and the popularity of football".<ref>{{cite news|author=CBC Sports |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/story/2008/03/08/fifa-instant-replay.html |title=FIFA halts instant replay experiment |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=8 March 2008 |accessdate=28 June 2010}}</ref>
A study suggested that in the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 Premier League season]] "errors took place nearly 30% of the time that video replays could help prevent", but some people claim that instant replays would interrupt the flow of the game and take away possible plays.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newelectronics.co.uk/electronics-technology/sport-technology-enables-improved-decisions/37425/ |title=Sport technology enables improved decisions |date=11 October 2011 |publisher=newelectronics.co.uk |accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref>
Other critics believe it would be prohibitively expensive to implement the technology at all levels of the game and particularly for smaller/poorer football associations. FIFA officials have expressed a preference for 'better refereeing' as well as more match officials over implementing the technology.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup-2010/teams/england/7857729/England-v-Germany-Fifa-want-better-refereeing-not-goal-line-technology.html |title=England v Germany: Fifa want 'better refereeing' not goal-line technology |newspaper=The Telegraph |date= 27 June 2010|accessdate=28 June 2010 | location=London | first=Paul | last=Kelso}}</ref> Advocates in turn cite the many examples of incorrect goal-line decisions deciding important games and point out that the technology has improved much since the initial trials carried out by FIFA. Advocates contend that any extra help for the referee should outweigh arguments that it would lead to non-uniform rules (since not all football associations would be able to implement it).
Blatter had been opposed to goal-line technology until [[Frank Lampard]]'s disallowed goal in the [[2010 World Cup]] where the ball clearly crossed the line.<ref name="july 2011"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/7061644/soccer-not-set-install-goal-line-aids-2013 |title=Soccer: No goal-line aids until 2013 |date=5 October 2011 |publisher=ESPN |location=London |accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2012/dec/11/michel-platini-goalline-technology-video|title=Michel Platini: goalline technology money would be better spent on grassroots – video|first=|last=theguardian.com|date=11 December 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
The introduction of [[Assistant referee (association football)#Additional assistant referee|additional assistant referees,]] who are mostly positioned beside the goal-line, was partly in order to facilitate in such situations.
===Cost===
In April 2013, [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] commissioner Don Garber confirmed that MLS would not adopt goal-line technology for the 2014 season, citing cost as the overriding factor. [[GoalControl]] installation would cost about $260,000 per stadium, and a further $3,900 for each game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/04/25/mls-commissioner-don-garber-says-league-wont-adopt-goal-line-technology-2014|title=mlssoccer.com - MLS Commissioner Don Garber says league won't adopt goal-line technology by 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
In early 2014, the vast majority of teams in the two divisions of the German [[Bundesliga]] voted against introducing goal-line technology for financial reasons. The costs per club would have ranged from €250,000 for a chip inside the ball up to €500,000 for Hawk-Eye or GoalControl. The manager of [[1. FC Köln]], [[Jörg Schmadtke]], summarized the vote with "The cost is so exorbitant, that using this (technology) is not acceptable".<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga-fuehrt-torlinientechnologie-vorerst-nicht-ein-a-960412.html Fußball: Bundesliga verzichtet auf Torlinientechnik], Spiegel Online, 2014-03-24.</ref>
World governing body FIFA are set to make £300,000 from the Premier League’s decision to install goal-line technology in all top-flight stadiums before the start of next season. Each of the 20 clubs will have to pay FIFA £15,000 to install, test and receive the ‘FIFA quality seal’ for Hawk-Eye’s camera-based system, which is expected to cost around £250,000 per ground in total. FIFA will also make an extra £15,000 from Wembley Stadium, which will have the technology installed for use in events such as the FA Cup semi-finals and final.
The [[Scottish Professional Football League]] stated in December 2017 that it would not be implementing goal-line technology, as it is only affordable for the richest leagues in Europe.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42504610 |title=Goal-line technology 'unaffordable' for Scottish Premiership |first=Jonathan |last=Sutherland |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=28 December 2017 |accessdate=28 December 2017}}</ref>

''Stadium Negara Hassanal Bolkiah'' | nickname = SNHB | image = | caption = | location = [[Bandar Seri Begawan]], [[Brunei]] | broke_ground = August 1980 | opened = 23 September 1983 | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Youth and Sports Department, Brunei | operator = Youth and Sports Department, Brunei | surface = Grass | construction_cost = S$100 million | architect = SAA Partnership | former_names = | tenants = [[Brunei national football team]]
[[Brunei DPMM FC]] | seating_capacity = 28,000https://int.soccerway.com/venues/brunei-darussalam/stadium-sultan-hassanal-bolkiah/v7779/ | dimensions = }} '''Hassanal Bolkiah National Stadium''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Bandar Seri Begawan]], [[Brunei]]. It is currently used mostly for [[association football]] matches. The stadium holds 28,000 and was opened in 1984. It was named after [[Sultan of Brunei|Bruneian Sultan]] [[Hassanal Bolkiah]]. == Construction == Unusually for a public building in Brunei, members of the public donated and contributed towards the building of the stadium. Although the final collection of $1,102,761.57 accounted for a little more than 1.1 percent of the total building cost ($100 million), the public participation showed the Bruneians' great interest and support for this project. The entire project cost for the stadium is about $100 million. == Opening == It was opened on 23 September 1983, the date was chosen to celebrate the 69th birthday of Bolkiah's father and predecessor [[Omar Ali Saifuddien III]]. On the evening of the opening day, a friendly football match was played between the [[Brunei national football team]] and an invited [[English Football League]] team, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]. Despite the jet lag and the humid weather, Sheffield United won 1–0. The next day another match was held between United and a Brunei invited team which ended in a 1-1 draw.[http://www.bt.com.bn/en/life/2008/10/26/national_stadium_celebrates_its_25th_year National Stadium celebrates its 25th year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090214074651/http://bt.com.bn/en/life/2008/10/26/national_stadium_celebrates_its_25th_year |date=2009-02-14 }} [[The Brunei Times]], 26 October 2008 == Major events == === 1999 === * [[1999 Southeast Asian Games|20th Southeast Asian Games]] on 7–15 August. === 2002 === * [[2002 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] on 16–26 August. === 2005 === * [[2005 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] on 13–25 March. === 2007 === * [[2007 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] on 3–12 March. === 2012 === * [[2012 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] on 9–23 August. === 2014 === * [[2014 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy|Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] on 24 February–9 March. ===International Soccer Matches=== {| class="wikitable" ! {{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=November 2017}}{{notability|1=Sport|date=November 2017}}}} {{Infobox football club |clubname=High Quality United |image=High Quality United logo.png |fullname=High Quality United Football Club |nickname= |founded= |ground=[[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]]
[[Thimphu]], [[Bhutan]] |coordinates= |capacity=25,000 |head coach=[[Pema]] |league=[[Thimphu League]] |season=[[2017 Bhutan National League#Thimphu League|2017]] |position =5th | }} '''High Quality United F.C.''' is a [[Association football|football]] club from [[Thimphu]], [[Bhutan]] who competes in the [[Thimphu League|Thimphu League]]. ==History== High Quality United first appeared in the [[2017_Bhutan_National_League#Thimphu_League|2017 Thimphu League]], in which they won 6 games, lost 7, and drew once against [[Bhutan_national_under-20_football_team|Bhutan U-19s]] with a score of 0–0{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan2017.html|title=Bhutan 2017|last=Stokkermans|first=Karel|date=6 October 2017|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=10 November 2017}}. They finished their inaugural season in 5th. As they did not place in the top 3, they did not qualify to the [[2017_Bhutan_National_League|2017 Bhutan National League]], but they were not relegated and will play again in the [[2018_Bhutan_National_League#Thimphu_League|2018 Thimphu League]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{A-Division seasons}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bhutan]] [[Category:Sport in Bhutan]] {{Bhutan-footyclub-stub}}

$31.4 million in 2012 dollars | tenants = [[McGill Redmen and Martlets|McGill Redmen]] ([[U Sports]]) (1915–present)
[[Montreal Alouettes]] ([[Canadian Football League|CFL]]) (1947–1967, 1972, 1998–present)
[[Montreal Royal (AUDL)|Montreal Royal]] ([[American Ultimate Disc League|AUDL]]) (2014–present) | architect = [[Percy Erskine Nobbs]] | seating_capacity = [[Canadian football]]: 25,012{{cite web|url=https://www.cfl.ca/article/als-well-in-montreal-in-pre-season-win|title='Als' well in Montreal in pre-season win|author=[[The Canadian Press]]|publisher=[[Canadian Football League]]|date=June 20, 2010|accessdate=January 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202155330/http://www.cfl.ca/article/als-well-in-montreal-in-pre-season-win|archivedate=December 2, 2010|df=}} }} '''Percival Molson Memorial Stadium''' (also known in [[French language|French]] as '''''Stade Percival-Molson'''''; commonly referred to as '''Molson Stadium''' in English or '''Stade Molson''' in French) is an outdoor [[Canadian football|football]] stadium located [[Downtown Montreal|downtown]] on the slopes of [[Mount Royal]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]]. Named in honour of [[Percival Molson]], it is owned by [[McGill University]] and has been the home of the [[Montreal Alouettes]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] from 1954 to 1967 and again from 1998 to present. The stadium is also home to the [[McGill Redmen]] of the [[RSEQ]], the [[Montreal Royal (AUDL)|Montreal Royal]] of the [[American Ultimate Disc League]], and the Canadian Corporate Soccer League, the largest amateur corporate league in Canada. The [[Selwyn House School|Selwyn House Gryphons]] high-school football team also play their home games at the stadium. The stadium has a capacity of 23,420 the result of a renovation project begun in 2009 that increased capacity from 20,202 to over 25,000, before seats were removed in 2014 to reduce capacity to its current level.{{cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/sports/football/cfl/montreal-alouettes/sold-out-molson-stadium-crowd-to-see-if-jacques-chapdelaine-can-turn-alouettes-around|title=Sold-out Molson Stadium crowd to see if Jacques Chapdelaine can turn Alouettes around|last=Zurkowsky|first=Herb|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|date=October 1, 2016|accessdate=August 11, 2017}} ==History== [[File:Montreal Alouettes vs. Hamilton Tiger-Cats, July 6 2006.jpg|thumb|[[Montreal Alouettes]] [[cheerleader]]s entertain the crowd during a timeout in a game against the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] on July 6, 2006, at Molson Stadium]] [[File:Football. At Molson Stadium BAnQ P48S1P06931.jpg|thumb|left|Football practice in 1941]] Construction was completed in 1914 on what was then known as McGill Graduates stadium, which was located on the slope of [[Mount Royal]], at the corner of University and Pine (avenue Des Pins). The stadium sat dormant through [[World War I]] with the cessation of football from 1914 to 1918. On July 5, 1917, Captain [[Percival Molson]] (1880–1917), a [[McGill University]] alumnus and sports star who had been instrumental in getting the stadium plan approved, was killed in action in [[France]] (Molson was the great-grandson of brewer [[John Molson]]). His will left $75,000 to the university to help pay most of the total costs for the completion of the stadium. Other individual donors whose generosity built and renovated the stadium were [[William C. Macdonald]] and [[John Wilson McConnell|John W. McConnell]]. Designed by [[Percy Erskine Nobbs]],[http://cac.mcgill.ca/campus/buildings/Gym.html ''Virtual McGill''] the stadium was officially dedicated as '''McGill Graduates' Stadium''' at an intercollegiate track meet on October 22, 1915. It was renamed Percival Molson Memorial Stadium on October 25, 1919 by the university's Board of Governors, in honour of their fallen hero. The Montreal Alouettes played at the stadium from 1954 to 1967 before moving to the [[Autostade]]. An attempted return to the Molson Stadium in 1972 was not successful and the team went back to the Autostade the following season. When a revived Alouettes franchise was forced to move a playoff game out of [[Olympic Stadium (Montreal)|Olympic Stadium]] due to a [[U2]] concert, they moved the game to Molson Stadium. The game was a sellout, prompting the Als to make Molson Stadium their primary home the following season. However, all playoff games are played at Olympic Stadium, which until 2007 hosted at least one home game as well. Percival Molson Stadium is also home of the [[Selwyn House School|Selwyn House]] Gryphons[http://www.versusfootball.com/showGame.action?gameId=6944&leagueId=14&newsId=7645 Versusfootball.com - Le site web ultime pour les équipes, joueurs et fans de football!] and the McGill [[McGill Redmen football|Redmen football]] and rugby teams. The only [[Grey Cup]] game to have been played at Molson Stadium was in 1931. Nevertheless, it was the first time the Grey Cup had been contested outside of Ontario. It also served as a venue for [[Field hockey at the 1976 Summer Olympics|field hockey]], during the [[1976 Summer Olympics]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1976/1976v2.pdf 1976 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 2. pp. 150-5. It seated 20,202 and had been sold out for Alouettes games from August 12, 1999 until the 2009 renovation.[http://en.montrealalouettes.com/article/the_cfl_publishes_the_2008_schedule The CFL Publishes The 2008 Schedule | Montreal Alouettes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304214200/http://en.montrealalouettes.com/article/the_cfl_publishes_the_2008_schedule |date=2012-03-04 }} The Alouettes' decision to return to the venue was problematic because the team was being sponsored by the [[Labatt Brewing Company]] and the stadium shared the name of its major competitor, [[Molson Brewery|Molson]], though not named for it. Eventually, the team chose to change sponsors and have been sponsored by Budweiser since 2014. In 2004, The Alouettes installed a [[FieldTurf]] surface at Molson Stadium replacing the old-style Astroturf. ==Renovation== Molson Stadium has been renovated and expanded, adding nearly 5,000 seats in time for the [[2010 CFL season]].[http://www.montrealkiosk.com/the-montrealer.php The Montrealer - Montreal Newspapers] The project to see the smallest CFL stadium increase to a [[seating capacity]] of 25,012 cost $29.4 million.[http://en.montrealalouettes.com/article/visiting-the-new-home Visiting the Alouettes' new home | Montreal Alouettes] Eleven rows were removed from the south side of the stadium to construct a second tier and add the majority of the new seats, about 3,800. Also, temporary bleachers in the east end-zone were replaced with 1,500 permanent seats, a new section was added to the northeast corner, and 19 new private suites were constructed. The cost of the renovations were shared by the [[Quebec]] government ($19.3 million), the city of Montreal ($4 million), and [[Robert Wetenhall]], the Alouettes' owner ($6,023,935).{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/Sports/Expansion+Montreal+Molson+Stadium+approved/1367728/story.html|title=Expansion of Montreal's Molson Stadium approved|last=Zurkowsky|first=Herb|publisher=Montreal Gazette|date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=March 9, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/story/2009/03/09/mtl-stadium-expansion.html|title=Molson Stadium to begin $29.4M expansion|publisher=CBC News|date=March 9, 2009|accessdate=March 10, 2009}}[http://en.montrealalouettes.com/article/percival-molson-stadium_47113 Expansion Project Approved | Montreal Alouettes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810033034/http://en.montrealalouettes.com/article/percival-molson-stadium_47113 |date=2011-08-10 }} ==Layout== Because the playing surface is surrounded by a running track, the full 65-yard width of the end zones is not available at the two end lines. However, the full width is available for more than half of each end zone, with the only missing pieces being the relatively small bits off the corners. Since the [[2014 CFL season]], it is the only stadium in the CFL to cut the corners on the end zones after Edmonton's [[Commonwealth Stadium (Edmonton)|Commonwealth Stadium]] squared off theirs. ==See also== *[[List of Canadian Football League stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Media== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100801090741/http://en.montrealalouettes.com/video/index/id/10431 Percival Molson Stadium under construction] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120528140703/http://en.montrealalouettes.com/video/index/id/12697/ Welcome to the brand new stadium!] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101106204831/http://en.montrealalouettes.com/video/index/id/14143 Alouettes luxury boxes available!] ==External links== {{Commons}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131010065816/http://mcgillathletics.ca/sports/2012/11/5/GEN_1105124126.aspx?tab=molsonstadium McGill University webpage for Percival Molson Memorial Stadium] {{1976 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues field hockey}} {{McGill}} {{Montreal Alouettes}} {{CFL Stadiums}} {{Coord|45|30|36.3|N|73|34|50.4|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Canadian Football League venues]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Canada]] [[Category:McGill Redmen football]] [[Category:Molson family]] [[Category:Montreal Alouettes]] [[Category:Sports venues in Montreal]] [[Category:Venues of the 1976 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic field hockey venues]] [[Category:Mount Royal]] [[Category:McGill University buildings]] [[Category:University sports venues in Canada]] [[Category:Percy Erskine Nobbs buildings]] [[Category:Ultimate (sport) venues]] [[Category:1915 establishments in Quebec]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1915]]

澳門賓菲加體育會 | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and age|1951|10|17|df=y|p=y|br=y}} | ground = [[Estádio Campo Desportivo]] | capacity = 16,272 | chairman = Duarte Alves | chrtitle = Team Manager | coach = [[Bernardo Tavares]] | league = [[Liga de Elite]] | season = [[2018 Liga de Elite|2018]] | position = 1st ''(champions)'' | pattern_la1 = _BenficaMacau18H | pattern_b1 = _BenficaMacau18H | pattern_ra1 = _BenficaMacau18H | pattern_sh1 = _BenficaMacau18H | pattern_so1 = | leftarm1 = dc1921 | body1 = | rightarm1 = dc1921 | shorts1 = dc1921 | socks1 = ffffff | pattern_la2 = _BenficaMacau18A | pattern_b2 = _BenficaMacau18A | pattern_ra2 = _BenficaMacau18A | pattern_sh2 = _BenficaMacau18A | pattern_so2 = | leftarm2 = dee2ea | body2 = dee2ea | rightarm2 = dee2ea | shorts2 = f5211b | socks2 = 000000 }} The '''House of Sport Lisboa e Benfica in Macau''' ({{zh|t=澳門賓菲加體育會}}), simply known as '''Benfica de Macau''', is a [[Macau|Macanese]] [[football (soccer)|football]] team which currently competes in the [[Liga de Elite]]. They are the five time defending champions of the league. The club was founded on 17 October 1951, as the House number 232 of [[S.L. Benfica]]. ==History== On 21 August 2016, Benfica de Macau defeated [[Rovers FC (Guam)|Rovers FC]] of Guam 4-2 in a [[2017 AFC Cup qualifying round|2017 AFC Cup Play-off Qualifier]] in [[Bishkek]]. It was the first win ever for a Macanese club in any AFC competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-afc.com/afc-cup-2017/duo-seal-key-2017-afc-cup-qualifying-wins-stalemate-in-group-c|title=DUO SEAL KEY 2017 AFC CUP QUALIFYING WINS, STALEMATE IN GROUP C|date=21 August 2016|website=''The AFC.com''}} In 2018, Benfica de Macau became the first Macanese club to participate in the [[2018 AFC Cup group stage|AFC Cup group stage]].{{cite web|url=https://macaudailytimes.com.mo/benfica-de-macau-kicks-off-season-highlighting-afc-cup.html|title=Benfica de Macau kicks off season highlighting AFC Cup|author=Renato Marques|date=18 January 2018|newspaper=''Macau Daily Times''}} On 7 March 2018, Benfica won 3-2 against Taiwan’s [[Hang Yuen FC|Hang Yuen]], becoming the first Macanese club to win an AFC group stage match.{{cite web|url=https://macaudailytimes.com.mo/benfica-wins-3-2-makes-history-local-football.html|title=BENFICA WINS 3-2 AND MAKES HISTORY FOR LOCAL FOOTBALL|date=7 March [[ŽŠD Celje]] (1951–1967)
[[NK Celje]] (1967–2003) | seating_capacity = 2,130 }} '''Skalna Klet Stadium''' ({{lang-sl|Stadion Skalna klet}}) or simply '''Skalna Klet''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Celje]], [[Slovenia]]. It was used for [[Association football|football]] matches and was the [[Home team|home ground]] of the [[Slovenian PrvaLiga]] team [[NK Celje]]. The stadium currently holds 3,000 spectators,https://int.soccerway.com/venues/slovenia/skalna-klet/v9810/ 2,130 of them can be seated. ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Slovenia]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://stadioni.org/celje/skalna-klet/ Stadioni.org profile] {{sl icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Skalna Klet}} [[Category:Football venues in Slovenia]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Slovenia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1904]]

{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Sophia Gardens Cardiff | website = http://www.thesseswalec.com/ | logo_image = Sophia-gardens-cardiff-logo.png | logo_caption = | image = Stadiwm SWALEC.JPG | caption = The Really Welsh Pavilion | nickname = ''Glamorgan Cricket Stadium'' | country = Wales | location = [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] | coordinates = {{coord|51|29|14|N|3|11|29|W|display=it}} | seating_capacity = 15,643<ref>{{cite news |title=Glamorgan secure England matches |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/glamorgan/8176020.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher= [[BBC]]|date=30 July 2009 |accessdate=31 July 2009 }}</ref> | owner = [[Cardiff City Council]] | architect = HLN Architects<ref>{{cite news|title=The Ashes – a Cardiff Success|url=http://www.hlnarchitects.com/uploads/downloads/Insight%20Sept%202009.pdf|publisher=HLN Architects|accessdate=25 May 2010}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> | end1 = River Taff End | end2 = Cathedral Road End | international = true | firsttestdate = 8–12 July | firsttestyear = 2009 | firsttesthome = England | firsttestaway = Australia | lasttestdate = 8–11 July | lasttestyear = 2015 | lasttesthome = England | lasttestaway = Australia | firstodidate = 20 May | firstodiyear = 1999 | firstodihome = Australia | firstodiaway = New Zealand | lastodidate = 16 June | lastodiyear = 2018 | lastodihome = England | lastodiaway = Australia | firstt20idate = 5 September | firstt20iyear = 2010 | firstt20ihome = England | firstt20iaway = Pakistan | lastt20idate = 6 July | lastt20iyear = 2018 | lastt20ihome = England | lastt20iaway = India | year1 = 1967–present | club1 = [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]] | date = 7 July | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/56874.html ESPNcricinfo }} '''Sophia Gardens Cardiff''' ({{lang-cy|Gerddi Soffia Caerdydd}}) is a [[cricket]] stadium in [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. It is located in [[Sophia Gardens]] on the [[River Taff]]. It is home to [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]] and is listed as an international [[List of Test cricket grounds|Test cricket venue]].
==County cricket== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header = The Cathedral Road End | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Sophia Gardens before the redevelopment.jpg | width1 = 180 | alt1 = | caption1 = Before the redevelopment | image2 = Cathedral Road end, SWALEC Stadium, Cardiff, Wales.jpg | width2 = 221 | alt2 = | caption2 = After the redevelopment }} The venue is home to [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club]] which has played its home matches there since 24 May 1967,<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/allaction/139727171/in/set-72057594124227176/ Pavilion Plaque, Sophia Gardens]</ref> after moving away from [[Cardiff Arms Park]]. A 125-year lease of the ground was acquired in 1995, with the previous leaseholders, [[Cardiff Athletic Club]], moving its cricket section ([[Cardiff Cricket Club]]) to the Diamond Ground in [[Whitchurch, Cardiff|Whitchurch]]. Beside the cricket ground is the large sports hall complex of the [[Sport Wales National Centre]]. [[Cardiff Corinthians F.C.]] have previously used the area for football. In July 2007, Glamorgan cricketer [[Mike Powell (cricketer)|Mike Powell]] was granted his wish to have a rib, removed during surgery, buried at the ground.<ref>[http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/glamorgan/content/story/302557.html Powell buries his rib at Sophia Gardens]</ref>
==International cricket== Sophia Gardens has been an international cricket venue since 20 May 1999, when it played host to the [[1999 Cricket World Cup]] match between [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] and [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]]. From 2001 to 2012, the ground was a regular venue for [[One Day International]]s, hosting nine matches in 12 years, but it was not until 2006 that it hosted its first [[England cricket team|England]] match, the first match of the series against [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] on 30 August 2006. In 2012, the ground was named as one of three venues for the [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]], along with [[The Oval]] and [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]]; it hosted five matches, including the opener between [[India national cricket team|India]] and [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] on 6 June 2013, and the semi-final between India and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] on 20 June.<ref name="champions">{{cite news |title=Glamorgan host more 2013 Champions Trophy games |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/19324236 |publisher=BBC Sport (British Broadcasting Corporation) |date=21 August 2012 |accessdate=13 April 2015 }}</ref> The ground also hosted two [[Twenty20 International]]s between England and Pakistan in September 2010, and it is due to host another against Australia in August 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ashes 2015: England and Australia open Test series in Cardiff |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/27371063 |publisher=BBC Sport (British Broadcasting Corporation) |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=13 April 2015 }}</ref>
On 11 April 2008, the [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] (ECB) announced that the venue would host a series of major Test matches over the next four years. It would host its first [[Test cricket|Test match]] on 8 July 2009 as the opening match of an [[The Ashes|Ashes]] series between England and Australia.<ref name="glamorgancricket.com">[http://www.glamorgancricket.com/news_view.php?news_id=1277 SWALEC Stadium awarded more international cricket] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926165111/http://www.glamorgancricket.com/news_view.php?news_id=1277 |date=2008-09-26 }}</ref> This made Sophia Gardens the 100th [[List of Test cricket grounds|Test match venue]]. In July 2011, the ECB stripped the ground of its right to host the 2012 [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] Test because of Glamorgan's late payment of the £2.5 million fee it owed for hosting the 2011 [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] Test.<ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/other-sport/cricket-swalec-test-match-loss-1818970 Cricket: Swalec Test match loss is confirmed]</ref> The ground was originally set to host a Test match against New Zealand in 2013, but this was given up in exchange for the 2013 Champions Trophy.<ref name="champions"/> The ground was chosen as the venue for the first Test of the [[2015 Ashes series]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Trent Bridge to host Ashes Tests in 2013 and 2015 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/15020210 |publisher=BBC Sport (British Broadcasting Corporation) |date=22 September 2011 |accessdate=13 April 2015 }}</ref>
{{wide image|Opening Ball.jpg|1000px|The opening ball of the 2009 Ashes series, bowled by [[Mitchell Johnson (cricketer)|Mitchell Johnson]] to [[Andrew Strauss]].}}
==Stadium redevelopment== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = Sophia Gardens after redevelopment | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Outside of the SWALEC Stadium.jpg | width1 = 180 | alt1 = | caption1 = Outside of the stadium | image2 = Really Welsh Pavilion, SWALEC Stadium.jpg | width2 = 180 | alt2 = | caption2 = The Really Wet Pavilion }} The £9.4 million cost to redevelop stadium was funded by with approximately half (£4.5 million) being provided in the form of a [[Cardiff Council]] loan.<ref>[http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/sports/cricket-news/2008/05/11/atherton-says-cardiff-ground-too-small-for-ashes-cricket-91466-20891059/ Atherton says Cardiff ground “too small” for Ashes cricket]</ref> It is possible that the revamped stadium could host seven Test matches, nine One Day Internationals and two [[Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] games up to 2028, injecting at least £50 million into the local economy.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4921718.stm Cardiff to host Ashes Test match]</ref><ref>[http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/england/content/story/244931.html Cardiff to host Ashes Test in 2009]</ref> Construction of the redevelopment of Sophia Gardens began in April 2007,<ref name="glamorgancricket.com"/> and the redeveloped stadium was first opened for competitive matches on 9 May 2008, when the Glamorgan Dragons played the [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire Gladiators]] in a [[Friends Provident Trophy]] match in which the Gladiators won by six wickets.<ref>[http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/sports/cricket-news/2008/05/10/cricket-gladiators-spoil-glamorgan-s-opening-night-party-91466-20889156/ Gladiators spoil Glamorgan’s opening-night party]</ref>
===Stadium naming rights===
{{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header = The logos used during the SWALEC sponsorship deal | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left | width = | image1 = Swalec Stadium logo.jpg | width1 = 193 | alt1 = | caption1 = Used from 2008 until 2015 | image2 = The-SSE-SWALEC-Logo.jpg | width2 = 180 | alt2 = | caption2 = Used from 2015 until early 2018 }} On 4 March 2008, Glamorgan Cricket Club announced a 10-year sponsorship deal with [[SWALEC]], thought to be the biggest single sponsorship by a county cricket club, giving SWALEC the naming rights to the new stadium, worth in excess of £1.5 million over 10 years.<ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/cricket-sophia-gardens-ground-renamed-2187086 Cricket: Sophia Gardens ground to be renamed Swalec Stadium]</ref>
In June 2015, ahead of the First Test of the [[2015 Ashes series]], the stadium was renamed as simply "The SSE SWALEC" in reflection of the ownership of sponsors SWALEC by [[SSE plc]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Gareth |last=Griffiths |title=Glamorgan rename ground as The SSE SWALEC ahead of Ashes showdown between England and Australia |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/glamorgan-rename-ground-sse-swalec-9390996 |work=Wales Online |publisher=Media Wales |date=4 June 2015 |accessdate=5 June 2015 }}</ref> The new logo from June 2015 was designed to reflect the shape of the stadium.<ref>[http://sse.com/newsandviews/allarticles/2015/06/new-name-for-wales-best-known-cricket-ground/ SSE]</ref> In April 2018 the stadium officially reverted to its traditional name of Sophia Gardens following the end of the sponsorship deal.<ref name=wo>Booth, Dominic (30 April 2018) [https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/cricket/glamorgan-cricket-cardiff-ashes-swalec-14595449 Iconic Cardiff sporting venue renamed as sponsorship deal comes to an end], ''[[Wales Online]]''. Retrieved 6 May 2018.</ref>
==See also== * [[List of international cricket centuries at Sophia Gardens]] * [[Sport in Cardiff]] * [[List of cricket grounds in England and Wales]] * [[List of sports venues with sole naming rights]] * [[Cricket Wales]]

{{Infobox venue | name = South Alabama Soccer Complex | nickname = "The Cage" | image = | fullname = | location = [[University of South Alabama]]
[[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]], [[Alabama]], [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|41|31|N|88|10|58|W|region:US|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1991 | renovated = | expanded = 2009 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of South Alabama]] | operator = [[University of South Alabama]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[South Alabama Jaguars|University of South Alabama Jaguars women's soccer team]] (1994-present) | capacity = 500 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} The '''South Alabama Soccer Complex''' is a [[soccer]] complex located on the campus of the [[University of South Alabama]] campus in [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]], [[Alabama]]. The facility is the home field of the [[South Alabama Jaguars|University of South Alabama Jaguars]] women's soccer team. The Cage hosted the [[Sun Belt Conference]] women's soccer tournament in 2000, 2002, 2005, 2007 and 2012. The complex has a capacity of 1,000 people. ==Expansion== In February 2009, the [[South Alabama Jaguars|University of South Alabama Jaguars]] women's soccer team moved into its newly constructed complex, which features a head coach's office, two assistant coaches' offices, locker room, training room, equipment room, conference room, and a player loungehttp://www.usajaguars.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=8300&KEY=&ATCLID=3671692&SPID=3252&SPSID=331149 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.usajaguars.com/ University of South Alabama Jaguars Athletics official website] {{University of South Alabama}} [[Category:Soccer venues in Alabama]] [[Category:South Alabama Jaguars sports venues]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Alabama]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]]

revision.text:
'''''The Darker Image''''' was the first all-[[African American|black]] female swimsuit [[wall calendar|calendar]] to break into mainstream bookstores across the United States, such as [[Barnes & Noble]] and [[Waldenbooks]], in 1994-1997.<ref name=lat94>{{cite news|last=Aubry|first=Erin|title=Banking On a Recipe of Class and Cheesecake; Photographer Ken Townsend Breaks Ground by Getting the First Swimsuit Calendar Featuring Black Women into Major Bookstores|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=2004-10-10|page=E1}}</ref>
Before [[King (magazine)|''King'']], [[Smooth (magazine)|''Smooth'']] and ''BlackMen'' magazines existed, black calendars such as ''The Darker Image'' were among the first to usher [[hip hop models]] into the mainstream print media (other than perhaps [[Jet (magazine)|''Jet'' magazine]]). ''The Darker Image'' was particularly well distributed and sat on shelves in [[Borders Group|Borders Books & Music]] and Barnes & Noble nationwide<ref name=lat94 /> and was featured on ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'', ''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]'', and ''[[The Jenny Jones Show]]''.<ref>Television show appearances can be viewed under the "Television" section under "Press" on the Darker Image website.</ref> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' quoted Barnes & Noble calendar buyer Bill Costello as saying, "The market is crying out for it. It's rare that you can say in the business, 'This is needed, there's nothing else like it.' In this case, it was true."<ref name=lat94 /> The Darker Image's distribution records for a minority-themed swimsuit calendar remain unbroken.
''The Darker Image'' calendar became a small part of the cultural zeitgeist of the time, particularly in the urban world, with the calendar prominently featured in John Singleton’s movie ''[[Higher Learning]]'', and [[The Hollywood Reporter]] writing: “‘Phat Beach,’ the first Hollywood beach blanket-type movie featuring blacks, has just wrapped principal photography.... Coolio and Paperboy will provide the rap tunes for the models from Darker Image '95 Swimsuit Calendar.”<ref>{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Donna|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|title=Leigh and Basinger goin' to 'Kansas City'|date=1995-01-05}}</ref>
''The Darker Image'' calendar did not feature any big name models or actresses at the time, although many of the models in the calendar went on to impressive careers, including [[Traci Bingham]], [[Melissa De Sousa]], [[Amy Hunter]], and [[Mari Morrow]].<ref>Bingham, DeSousa, and Hunter appeared in the 1996 Darker Image Calendar; Morrow appeared in 1994 Darker Image Calendar.</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.darkerimagecalendar.com Darker Image Website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLV8sFst16A&feature=channel_page YouTube link]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Darker Image, The}} [[Category:African-American media]] [[Category:Published calendars]] [[Category:Swimsuits]]
{{AfricanAmerican-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} '''Warrender Swim Centre''' – traditionally known as '''Warrender Baths''' – is a [[swimming pool]] and fitness complex in [[Marchmont]], [[Edinburgh]].
[[File:Warrender Baths, Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|Entrance to Warrender Baths]] It consists of a pool {{convert|25|yd}} in length, a sauna, and an assortment of fitness equipment. It is notable for its [[Victorian architecture]] with bright interior and its old-fashioned poolside changing facilities. The baths enjoy category "B" [[listed building]] conservation status.<ref>Staff (19 March 1993) [http://data.historic-scotland.gov.uk/pls/htmldb/f?p=2200:15:0::::BUILDING:30607 Warrender baths, Thirlestane Road] City of Edinburgh Council, Statutory List, Category B, Retrieved 21 March 2013</ref>
==History== In 1886, some Edinburgh residents and members of the Bellahouston Private Baths Club, Glasgow, decided to build a swimming club in Edinburgh. Frank Y. Henderson therefore formed the Warrender Private Baths Club Limited which bought some land from Sir [[Sir George Warrender, 7th Baronet|George Warrender]], 6th Baronet,<ref name = Gazetteer>[http://www.scottish-places.info/features/featurefirst16889.html Gazetteer for Scotland - Warrender Swim Centre] Accessed 31 October 2011</ref> and, using the local architect Robert Paterson, had the baths built. The original cost was £11,000 and the baths were opened on Saturday 17 December 1887 by Sir George.<ref name =WBC>[http://www.swimwarrender.com/pages/43/Club_History.html Warrender Baths Club, History] Accessed 5 April 2010.</ref><ref name =WBC2>Gilmore, J., editor (1990) "A Hundred Years of Warrender Baths Club 1888-1988" Warrender Baths Club, Edinburgh {{ISBN|0-9516787-0-1}}</ref>
Warrender Baths differed from many similar facilities in Edinburgh in that they were originally built privately with the emphasis on fitness and leisure. Many of the city's comparable swimming pools were part of a much wider scheme to build public baths to promote cleanliness and hygiene amongst the working classes, who did not have routine access at the time to sanitation. Warrender Baths also sported a billiard room and a reading room.
Initially the facilities were a success, but by 1906 were no longer viable and were closed. They were bought by the city for £3000, where they joined the city's portfolio of similar pools. Periodically suffering further closure threats, they were refurbished in 2005<ref name = Gazetteer/> and are now secure.
The baths are home to the [[Warrender Baths Club]] which is said to be the oldest, most famous and most successful swimming club in Scotland.<ref name =WBC/> [[David Wilkie (swimmer)|David Wilkie]] the Olympic gold medallist swimmer,<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/wi/david-wilkie-1.html David Wilkie Biography] Accessed 5 April 2010</ref> [[Ellen King]] and [[Keri-Anne Payne]]<ref>Magnay, Jacqueline (29 December 2012) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/9770763/Keri-Anne-Payne-considers-switching-to-the-pool-after-the-pain-of-fourth-at-London-Olympics.html Keri-Anne Payne considers switching to the pool after the pain of fourth at London Olympics] The Telegraph, Retrieved 24 January 2013</ref> both silver Olympic medallists, bronze medal Olympic swimmers [[Paul Easter]], [[Gordon Downie (swimmer)|Gordon Downie]] and [[Alan McClatchey]], bronze Paralympic medal winners George Simpson<ref name = WBC/> and [[Sean Fraser (swimmer)|Sean Fraser]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport/London-calling-as-Fraser-nets.4481126.jp |title=London calling as Fraser nets bronze in 100m clash |work=[[Edinburgh Evening News]] |date=11 September 2008 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> and Olympic finalist [[Jean McDowell]] swam and trained with Warrender Baths Club.<ref name = WBC2/>
In November 2009, a swimming customer at Warrender Swim Centre was hit with glass due to a glazing fault, resulting in an injury to his arm and requiring the closure of the centre as a precautionary measure to ensure the safety of customers.<ref>[http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/edinburgh/Pool-shut-after-glass-panel.5802126.jp Pool shut after glass panel falls on swimmer] 6 November 2009, Accessed 28 June 2010</ref> The baths were opened again in June 2010.<ref>[http://www.edinburghleisure.co.uk/list-115 The wait over - Warrender swimming pool is open again!] 21 June 2010, Accessed 28 June 2010</ref>
==See also== *[[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]] – one of the oldest swimming baths in Edinburgh was at the first purpose-built site of the hospital
==References== <references/> * [http://living.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=181092006 Article in ''The Scotsman'' about Warrender Baths]
==External links== *[https://www.edinburghleisure.co.uk/venues/warrender-swim-centre#joinus]
